{{Orphan|date=December 2016}}
The '''Messianic Jewish Theological Institute''' was established by the [[Union of Messianic Jewish Congregations]] (UMJC) in 2002.<ref name="UMJC">{{cite web|url=http://www.umjc.org/mjti/|title=Messianic Jewish Theological Institute|publisher=}}</ref><ref name="UMJC 2">{{cite web|url=http://www.umjc.org/mjti-messianic-jewish-theological-institute/|title=MJTI – Messianic Jewish Theological Institute|publisher=}}</ref> It is a [[Messianic Jewish]] school<ref name="Schools">{{cite web|url=http://www.messianicjudaism.net/schools.html|title=Schools|publisher=}}</ref> "rooted in a contemporary Jewish experience of Yeshua and a Messianic interpretation of [[Judaism]]."<ref name=mission>{{cite web|title=Mission Statement|url=http://www.mjti.org/about/mission|publisher=Messianic Jewish Theological Institute}}</ref> It is also a "dialogue center for theological encounter between faithful [[Christians]] and [[Jews]]"<ref name=mission /> and an international learning community "born in the Diaspora but oriented to Israel."<ref name=mission />
The institute is located in [[San Diego]], [[California]],<ref name=Contact>{{cite web|url=http://www.mjti.org/about/contact|title=Contact Us|publisher=Messianic Jewish Theological Institute}}</ref> but offers courses through a variety distance learning modalities.<ref name=home>{{cite web|title=Home page|url=http://www.mjti.org/|publisher=Messianic Jewish Theological Institute}}</ref>
== Faculty == MJTI's faculty includes scholars such as [[David J. Rudolph]], Stuart Dauermann<ref name="OJS">{{cite web|url=http://ojs.globalmissiology.org/index.php/english/article/view/226/630|title=Article Download|publisher=}}</ref> (Ph.D. Intercultural Studies, [[Fuller Seminary]]), David Friedman (Ph.D. Near Eastern Studies, [[California Graduate School of Theology]]), Vered Hillel (Ph.D. 2nd Temple Period Judaism, [[Hebrew University of Jerusalem]]), Mark S. Kinzer (Ph.D. Near Eastern Studies, [[University of Michigan]]), Carl Kinbar (DLitt. et Phil. Early Judaism, [[University of South Africa]]), and Jennifer Rosner (Ph.D. Systematic Theology, [[Fuller Theological Seminary]]).<ref name=faculty>{{cite web|url=http://www.mjti.org/about/faculty|title=Faculty|publisher=Messianic Jewish Theological Institute}}</ref>
== Founding President == Emeritus President Rabbi Dr. Mark Kinzer.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.christianitytoday.com/ct/2005/february/31.76.html|title=Jacob vs. Jacob|publisher=}}</ref>
==Board of directors== The MJTI Board of Trustees "provides legal, academic, financial and administrative oversight to the School of Jewish studies."<ref name=board>{{cite web|url=http://www.mjti.org/about/board-of-directors|title=Board of Directors|publisher=Messianic Jewish Theological Institute}}</ref> Current Board members include * Elliot Klayman, Esq., Trustee Chair (Emeritus Associate Professor of Business Law, [[The Ohio State University]])<ref>http://www.messianicstudiesinstitute.org/bio/?id=309</ref> * Rabbi Russell Resnik<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.com/Russell-Resnik/e/B001K7S5YK|title=Amazon.com: Russell Resnik: Books, Biography, Blog, Audiobooks, Kindle|publisher=}}</ref> (Executive Director, [[Union of Messianic Jewish Congregations]])<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mjti.org/about/board-of-directors|title=Board of Directors – MJTI School of Jewish Studies|publisher=}}</ref> * Rabbi Paul Saal (Rabbi, Congregation Shuvah Yisrael, and vice president of the Messianic Jewish Rabbinical Council).<ref>http://ourrabbis.org/main/members/member-profiles/item/17-rabbi-paul-l-saal</ref>
== References == {{reflist}}
[[Category:Messianic Judaism]] [[Category:Jewish seminaries]]

{{Islam}}
'''Morality in Islam''' is a comprehensive term that serves to include the [[concept]] of [[righteousness]], good [[Moral character|character]], and the body of moral qualities and [[virtue]]s prescribed in [[Islamic holy books|Islamic religious texts]]. The underlying idea of Islamic [[morality]] is that of [[love]]: love for [[God in Islam|God]] and love for God's creatures. The idea is that mankind will acquire and follow the body of moral qualities in order to seek God's pleasure and to [[Philanthropy|treat the fellow human beings in the best possible manner]].<ref>Leaman (2006), p. 416</ref><ref name=Moral>[http://www.islamreligion.com/articles/1174/moral-system-of-islam-part-1/ Moral System of Islam: The Standard of Morality.] (2006). ''IslamReligion.com'' Retrieved 19 Aug 2016.</ref>
Teaching on [[morality]] and moral conduct constitute a basic principle of [[Islam]], and the moral themes form a large part of it. The [[Quran]] and the [[Hadith]] – the central religious texts of Islam – serve as the primary source for it.<ref name=Clark-283>Clark (2011), p. 283</ref> Both the Quran and the hadith often speak in emphatic manners to instruct the Muslims to adopt a morally good [[Moral character|character]]. Showing [[kindness]] to people, and [[Charity (practice)|charity]] to the poor and the helpless are the most highlighted and most insisted virtues in the Quran.<ref>Leaman (2006), p. 415</ref> In particular, helping people especially in their needs, [[Forgiveness|forgiving others' offenses]], respecting [[parent]]s and elders, fulfilling promises, being kind to people and to animals, being patient in adversaries, maintaining [[justice]], [[Honesty|being honest]] in nature, controlling [[anger]] come as major virtues in Islamic concept of morality.
==Sources== The Quran, which Muslims believe to be the verbatim word of God, serves as the primary source of moral teachings in Islam.<ref name= Clark-283/> The [[Sunnah]], which is the teachings, deeds and sayings, silent permissions (or disapprovals) of the [[Prophets of Islam|Islamic prophet]] [[Muhammad]], as well as various reports about Muhammad's companions, also serves as an important source for Islamic moral teachings.<ref name= Clark-283/> Besides these, the works of Islamic scholars and philosophers, and the moral examples set by important Islamic personalities (such as the four rightly guided caliphs) are other sources for Islamic ethical and moral guidance.<ref name= Clark-283/>
==General principle== Islamic primary sources and later Islamic scholarly works have made detailed discussions and laid down detailed instructions on moral issues. However, some general principles can be found in case of following morality. One typical Islamic teaching on morality is that imposing a penalty on an offender in proportion to their offense is permissible and just; but forgiving the offender is better. To go one step further by offering a favor to the offender is regarded the highest excellence.<ref name="Nigosian 2004, p.116">Nigosian (2004), p.116</ref> Another principle is that whatever is good and beneficial for mankind is morally good, and vice versa.<ref name=Moral/> According to Islamic [[sharia]], a Muslim is expected to act only in good manners<ref>Leaman (2006), p.252</ref> as bad manners earn vices. Muhammad is reported as saying "It is not possible that you indulge in rebuking and reviling and remain righteous at the same time".<ref name="Al-Ghazali, chp. 14">Al-Ghazali, chp. 14.</ref>
==Significance== Much emphasis has been attached in Islamic tradition on developing strong moral [[Value (ethics)|values]]. [[Iman (concept)|Faith]] is considered incomplete without having sense of morality.<ref>Al-Ghazali, chp. 2.</ref> In Islamic sharia, a worshiper devoid of morality is seen as someone who has failed to realize the true significance of worshiping. In other words, the [[Salat|prayers]] which can not keep a person away from wrongdoings are seen worthless.<ref>Maariful Quran. Chapter 29, verse 45.</ref> Muhammad is reported as saying that a real poor person is he who will appear on the [[Day of Judgment]] with a lot of rewards earned by his [[Salah|prayers]], [[Sawm|fasting]], [[zakat]]; but in his life he had also abused someone, had falsely accused someone, had illegally taken another's property, had murdered somebody; so all his virtues will be distributed to the victims, and he will be thrown to hell ({{Hadith-usc|usc=yes|muslim|32|6251}}). Islamic tradition holds that moral qualities and good actions elevate the status of a man.<ref name="Nigosian 2004, p.116"/> Since the pursuance of moral qualities are more of a voluntary nature, their observance falls into the category of supererogatory worshipping, and is seen as the key to attaining the nearness of God.<ref name=Leaman-139>Leaman (2006), p. 139-143</ref> Islamic prophet [[Muhammad]] said, "The best among you are those who have the best manners and character" ({{Hadith-usc|bukhari|usc=yes|8|73|56}}).
==Emphasis on good character== [[Moral character|Character]] primarily refers to the assemblage of qualities that distinguish one individual from another. Character can be good or bad. A good character is the one that has good moral qualities. There was a debate among the early Islamic [[Moral philosopher|moralists]] as to whether character could be changed. They recognized the dual aspect of character – innate and acquired – and thus noted that with conscious practice it could be changed to a certain degree.<ref name=Leaman-139/>
As a [[religion]], Islam promotes the idea of good character as is evident from its canonical texts. The Quran describes Muhammad as being 'on exalted quality of character' ({{cite quran|68|4|s=ns|b=n}}) and refers to him as 'an excellent example' ({{cite quran|33|21|s=ns|b=n}}) which ultimately means that the religious and moral examples, set by Muhammad, are to be followed and cultivated by the Muslims in order to construct a morally good character.<ref name=Leaman-139/> Muslim moralists have discussed the [https://en.oxforddictionaries.com/definition/us/ethico-religious ethico-religious] importance of having a good character as well as the ways of acquiring it. [[Imam Birgivi]], a 16th century Muslim scholar and moralist, says that 'To cure yourself of a bad feature of character is an obligation'.<ref>Birgivi (2005), p.110</ref> Continuous practice of moral virtues and a conscious effort to internalize those qualities can lead to the formation of a morally good character.<ref name=Leaman-139/><ref>Birgivi (2005), p.108</ref> [[Al-Raghib al-Isfahani|Al-Isfahani]] says that purification of soul means the control, not the elimination, of desires. According to Birgivi, changing of character depends on such things as 'a person's wish' and 'the strength of one's understanding', and the preservation of a good character requires the avoidance of the company of evil-charactered people who indulge into indecent activities, drunkenness, and meaningless gossip.<ref name= Birgivi-111>Birgivi (2005), p.111</ref> There are numerous sayings of Muhammad that highlight the importance of good character. Some of them are: * Anas ibn Malik reported that the Prophet said: The one with good morals and character already owns the best of this world and the Hereafter (Tabarani and [[Sunan Abi Dawood|Abu Dawud]]).<ref name= Birgivi-111/> * Abu Hurayrah reported that the Prophet said: I have been sent for the perfection of character ([[Musnad Ahmad Ibn Hanbal|Imam Ahmad]] and Bayhaqi).<ref name= Birgivi-111/> * Anas ibn Malik reported that the Messenger of Allah said: A person reaches the best and most honored levels in the Hereafter as a result of good character…. And bad character condemns a person to the lowest depths of Hell (Tabarani).<ref name= Birgivi-111/> * One can repent for any sin but bad character – because with bad character, before a person can attempt to ask forgiveness for one sin, he commits a worse (Tabarani, Isfahani).<ref name= Birgivi-111/>
==Major virtues==
===Charity and philanthropy === {{Rquote|right|O Aisha, Never turn away any needy man from your door empty-handed. Love the poor; bring them near to you and God will bring you near to Him on the Day of Resurrection.|[[Muhammad]]|''Rahman, Encyclopedia of Seerah, VOL. VIII, p. 151''}}
Numerous verses of the Quran and the sayings of Muhammad tell the [[Muslim]]s to be [[Generosity|generous]] with their wealth and to [[Philanthropy|respond to the calls of the mankind's needs]]. Muslims believe that spending wealth for others, especially for the needy, and helping people are a fundamental duty for them,<ref>Stefon (2010), p. 92</ref> and these things earn [[God]]'s mercy and reward in the [[afterlife]]. Similarly, caring for one's kinsmen and [[Neighbourhood|neighbors]] has also been emphasized. The Quran says that the righteous are those people who fulfill their promises, and feed the needy, [[Orphan|the orphans]] and the captive for the love of God ({{cite quran|76|5-8|s=ns|b=n}}). At another place, it says "Those who (in charity) spend their goods by night and by day, in secret and in public have their reward with their Lord; on them shall be no fear, nor shall they grieve" ({{cite quran|2|274|s=ns|b=n}}). In a long hadith collected in [[Sahih Muslim]], Jarir narrates that once they were with Muhammad when some poor people came. They were ill-clad with torn dresses and were starving. When Muhammad saw them, the color of his face changed. He asked [[Bilal ibn Ribah|Bilal]] to assemble the people and then delivered a speech, and said "Everyone should give in charity dinar, dirham, cloth, dates, wheat, etc." He went on till he urged: "Give, even if it is a stone of a date." After this, a man from [[Ansar (Islam)|Ansar]] brought a bag so full of materials that it was slipping from his hand. Other people also brought things to be given in charity till there were two big heaps of eatable goods and clothes. At that, the face of Muhammad glowed with joy.<ref name= Ghazali-15>Al-Ghazali, chp. 15.</ref>
[[Miser|Miserliness]] is discouraged in Islam,<ref>Nigosian (2004), p.117</ref> and the hoarding of wealth which is not used to redress the miseries of the needy and the poor is seen to be a cause of punishment in the afterlife.<ref name= Ghazali-15/> Helping people in time of their needs is seen more important than praying in the mosque.<ref>Hashmi (2009), p. 68-9</ref>
===Forgiveness=== {{See also|Repentance in Islam}} As a virtue, [[forgiveness]] is much celebrated in Islam, and is regarded as an important Muslim practice, inspired by both the Quran and the Sunnah. The issue of forgiveness can take on two different forms: God's forgiveness for human beings for their [[sin]]s, and forgiveness among fellow human beings for each other. In the first instance, human beings have been asked to seek God's forgiveness for their sins, and they have been promised God's mercy and forgiveness. In the second instance, human beings have been encouraged to practice the act of forgiveness among themselves.<ref name=Leaman-213>Leaman (2006), p. 213-16</ref> To forgive a person who has done moral offense, and not to be cruel to him is seen as a noble virtue.<ref name=MQ-7-199>Maariful Quran. Chapter 7, verse 199.</ref> In Islamic theology, the act of forgiveness is not meant to deny or underplay the moral injury suffered by the victim; rather it involves a positive change in mentality toward the offender.<ref name=Leaman-213/> Thus, an act of forgiveness means rising above one's self-interest or narrow-mindedness, and achieving nobler quality of heart. Those who practice the act of forgiveness have been promised reward by [[God in Islam|God]].<ref>Mohammad Hassan Khalil. (2012). ''Islam and the Fate of Others: The Salvation Question.'' Oxford University Press. pp 65-94. {{ISBN|978-0199796663}}</ref> In a frequently quoted hadith, Muhammad is reported as saying: 'the best deeds before God are to pardon a person who has wronged you, to show affection for relatives who have broken ties with you, and to act generously towards a person who has deprived you.'<ref name=Leaman-213/><ref name=MQ-7-199/>
===Tolerance=== In Islamic context, to be tolerant of one another comes both as a teaching and an injunction which is to be cultivated at personal, social, and religious levels. After its introduction in 610 CE, Islam sought to moderate the violent attitudes, prevalent among the people of [[pre-Islamic Arabia]], with the practice of tolerance and other virtues.<ref name="Al-Ghazali, chp. 14">Al-Ghazali, chp. 14.</ref><ref>Leaman (2006), p.414-5</ref> Islam expects people to practice tolerance in their family and social life. It is the teaching of Islam that when faced with ill-treatment by any unwise person, a sensible person should be less reactive and more tolerant. The misbehavior of others should not provoke him to do the same.<ref name="Al-Ghazali, chp. 14"/> During the initial years of Islam, Muslims faced persecutions by the Meccan pagans.<ref name=EI-Muhammad>Buhl, F.; Welch, A. T. (1993). "Muḥammad". [[Encyclopaedia of Islam]] '''7'''. pp. 360–376.</ref> During this period, Muhammad was once asked by his companions to invoke God's wrath on the persecutors. Muhammad became displeased with such a request and advised them to be more tolerant.<ref>Khan (1980), p. 40</ref> Once a [[Bedouin]] became discontented and expressed his dissatisfaction even after receiving gifts from Muhammad. Muhammad understood his nature, showed tolerance to him, and satisfied him with more gifts, thus paving the way for the Bedouin to take lesson from this.<ref name="Al-Ghazali, chp. 14"/> In the [[History of Islam]], [[Abd-Allah ibn Ubayy|Abdullah ibn Ubayy]] was known as the "leader of the [[Munafiq| hypocrites]]".<ref>William Montgomery Watt, "Abdullah b. Ubayy", ''[[Encyclopaedia of Islam]]''</ref> The activities of the hypocrites were condemned by several verses in the Quran. After Ubayy's death, at his son's request, Muhammad offered his own shirt as Ubayy's shroud.<ref name="Al-Ghazali, chp. 14" /><ref name=MQ-4-438>Maariful Quran. Vol 4, p. 438. (Sura 9, verse 84.)</ref> At his son's second request, Muhammad even led his funeral prayer.<ref>{{cite book |last= Haykal |first=Muhammad Husayn |authorlink=Muhammad Husayn Haykal |title=The Life of Muhammad |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=fOyO-TSo5nEC&pg=PA486 |year=2008 |publisher=Islamic Book Trust |location=[[Selangor]] |isbn=978-983-9154-17-7 |page=486}}</ref><ref name="Al-Ghazali, chp. 14" /><ref name=MQ-4-438/> When [[Umar]] objected about this, Muhammad said: "If I knew that Allah will pardon Ubayy if I pray for his forgiveness more than seventy times, I would even do that."<ref>{{cite book |last=Abdur Raheem |first=M. R. M. |title=Muhammad the Prophet |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_nImTioI7ygC&pg=PA712|year=1988 |publisher=Pustaka Nasional Pte Ltd |location= |isbn=9789971772239 |page=712}}</ref><ref>Maariful Quran. Vol 4, p. 441. (Sura 9, verse 84.)</ref>
On social and state levels, the importance of tolerance comes from the fact that it is related to such greater issues as [[peace]] and justice which are said to be the desired goal of Islam.<ref name=Leaman-655>Leaman (2006), p. 655-57</ref> Given that diversity is a natural phenomenon in this world, the Quran puts much emphasis on the observance of tolerance in order to maintain peace and security. In {{cite quran|49|13|s=ns|b=n}}, the Quran recognizes the diversity among people: 'O mankind! We created you from a single (pair) of a male and a female, and made you into nations and tribes, that ye may know each other (not that ye may despise each other). Verily the most honoured of you in the sight of Allah is (he who is) the most righteous of you.' By mentioning the common origin of mankind, the Quran reminds them of their relating to each other, and urges them to 'rise above' the racial and national divisions.<ref name=Leaman-655/> In a nutshell, it is the teaching of Islam that the diversity or difference in social, cultural, political, or religious spheres are to be accepted by members of communities to secure a peaceful co-existence.<ref name=Leaman-655/> About religious tolerance, the Quran says: 'Let there be no compulsion in religion' ({{cite quran|2|256|s=ns|b=n}}).{{primary source inline|date=December 2017}} No forceful conversion is recognized in Islam. According to Islamic jurists, [[forced conversion]] is not possible in Islam because [[Iman (concept)|faith]] basically relates to heart, and not so much to external affairs.<ref>Maariful Quran. Chapter 2, verse 256.</ref>
===Honesty=== In Islam, [[honesty]] implies maintaining [[sincerity]] and truthfulness in all actions, interactions, and transactions, and the issue of honesty touches almost all aspects of human life. Here, honesty serves as a umbrella term having some basic components like speaking truth; fulfilling commitments, whether written or verbal; remaining truthful to one's word; rendering the assigned duty sincerely and as meticulously as possible; imparting everyone's due rights without the person's asking for it; being objective in evaluating any case and giving judgments; avoiding falsehood, deception, and favoritism.<ref name=Alkhuli-12>Alkhuli (2006), p. 12-3</ref> Selection and promotion of personnel in an organization based on merit and not on favoritism is also a part of honesty. As Islam is a God-centered religion, honesty demands that it be maintained not only in public but also in private, not only when supervised but also when not supervised.<ref name=Alkhuli-12/> Honesty has particularly been emphasized in [[Financial transaction|business transactions]], not only in selling and buying but in issues like [[Price controls|pricing]] and [[advertising]] policies. Correct measurement is to be maintained. Again, Muhammad has instructed that the sellers should put the commodities of poorer quality in clear display so that the customers are not deceived.<ref>Clark (2011), p.297</ref> [[Price gouging|Hiking the price]] to gain more profit or lowering the price to put the competitors at trouble are considered unethical.<ref>Ali (2015), p. 169</ref> Similarly, exaggerated claims and suppression of unfavorable information in advertising are discouraged.<ref>Ali (2015), p. 169-170</ref> Honesty is regarded by Muslim scholars as one of the five essential qualities for any Muslim accountants.<ref>Ali (2015), p. 264</ref>
===Kindness and leniency=== The Quran and the hadith describe God as being kind and merciful to His creatures, and tell people to be kind likewise. Among the [[99 Names of God]] in Islam, the most common and famous are "the Compassionate" (al-raḥmān) and "the Merciful" (al-raḥīm).<ref>Bentley, David (1999). ''The 99 Beautiful Names for God for All the People of the Book.'' William Carey Library. {{ISBN|0-87808-299-9}}.</ref> The Quran says, "Verily, Allah is kind and merciful to the people" ({{cite quran|2|143|s=ns|b=n}}). Numerous sayings of Muhammad tell the Muslims to be kind and merciful to the creatures of God. In Sahih Bukhari, it is said "He who is not merciful to others, will not be treated mercifully (by God)" ({{Hadith-usc|bukhari|usc=yes|8|73|42}}). Narrated in Sahih Muslim, Muhammad said, "Verily, Allah is mild and is fond of mildness, and He gives to the mild what He does not give to the harsh"<ref name="D'Silva-129"/> ({{Hadith-usc|usc=yes|muslim|32|6273}}). He also said, "He who is deprived of kindness is in fact deprived of goodness ({{Hadith-usc|usc=yes|muslim|32|6272}}).
Muhammad has been described as being kind and compassionate to people and animals. [[Prophetic biography|Biographies of Muhammad]] record incidences showing his [[kindness]] and leniency to others. Once, a man came to him and said that he had committed a certain sin. As reparation for his sin, Muhammad asked the man if he could [[Islamic views on slavery|free a slave]] upon which the man expressed his inability. Muhammad asked him if he could [[Sawm|fast]] for two months upon which the man replied in the negative. Muhammad asked him again if he could feed sixty poor men upon which the man replied that he was even unable to do that. In the meantime, a bag of dates was brought there as gift for Muhammad. Muhammad gave the bag of dates to the man and told him to distribute the dates among the poor as reparation. The man passionately said "who is poorer than me in [[Medina]]?" Hearing this, Muhammad smiled and told the man to distribute the dates among his own family members.<ref name=Shibli-2>Shibli Nomani, vol 2</ref>
===Kind treatment to animals=== Islam has prescribed kind treatment not only to humans but also to animals.<ref name="D'Silva-129">D'Silva (2012), p. 129</ref> Prophet Muhammad was probably the first in history to talk about the [[Animal rights|rights and proper treatment of animals]].<ref name="D'Silva-129"/><ref name=Animal-1>Imam Kamil Mufti (2006). [http://www.islamreligion.com/articles/185/humane-treatment-of-animals/ Humane Treatment of Animals.] ''IslamReligion.com'' Retrieved 19 Aug 2016.</ref>{{Disputed inline|date=September 2018}} Kind and humane treatment earn virtue, and can even be a means of salvation. Similarly, cruelty towards animals can lead to punishment by God.<ref name="D'Silva-130">D'Silva (2012), p. 130</ref> Islamic tradition narrates the story of a man who got salvation for showing mercy to a thirsty dog.<ref name="D'Silva-130">D'Silva (2012), p. 130</ref> On one occasion, the man saw a [[dog]] which was about to die because of extreme thirst. He realized its plight, went down into a well, brought some water for the dog, and saved its life. God became pleased with him and pardoned all his previous sins ({{Hadith-usc|bukhari|usc=yes|8|73|38}}). It also narrates the story of a woman who locked up a cat. She neither fed the cat nor set it free to feed for itself. For her cruelty, she was punished by God.<ref name="D'Silva-130"/> The early rulers in Islamic world used to instruct people in behaving properly to the animals.<ref name="D'Silva-132">D'Silva (2012), p. 132</ref>
For proper treatment of animals, Islam has specified some guidelines: * All pet and farm animals have the rights of proper food and shelter. The owner has the obligation to arrange for food and shelter for his animals.<ref name=Animal-1>Imam Kamil Mufti (2006). [http://www.islamreligion.com/articles/185/humane-treatment-of-animals/ Humane Treatment of Animals.] ''IslamReligion.com'' Retrieved 19 Aug 2016.</ref><ref name="D'Silva-130"/> * Animals which are used to carry goods should not be over-loaded.<ref name="D'Silva-131">D'Silva (2012), p. 131</ref> * Animals must not be tortured, beaten, or hurt unnecessarily. They are not to be killed for recreation. Also, the body parts of any live animal must not be mutilated.<ref name=Animal-1/><ref name="D'Silva-131"/> * Islam has prohibited the old custom of setting live animals or birds as targets for shooting practices.<ref name=Animal-1/><ref name="D'Silva-131"/> * Prophet Muhammad has forbidden separating the birds from their off-springs.<ref name="D'Silva-131"/> * Animal slaughtering process should be such which is the least painful to the animal. Slaughtering of one animal in front of another is prohibited in Islam.<ref name=Animal-1/><ref name="D'Silva-132"/>
===Justice=== {{Rquote|right| To render justice ranks as the most noble of acts of devotion next to belief in God. It is the greatest of all the duties entrusted to the prophets…and it is the strongest justification for man’s stewardship of earth.|[[Sarakhsi|Shams al-Din Sarkhasi]]|''Al-Mabsut, vol. 14, p. 59-60''}}
The Quran uses the words ''adl'', ''qist'', ''qast'', ''wasat'', and ''mizan'' in referring to [[justice]], with the word ''adl'' being mostly used and literally meaning to straighten, to balance, to depart from wrong, or to be equal.<ref>Khadduri (1984), p. 6</ref> Its meaning is thus "a combination of moral and social values denoting fairness, balance, temperance and straightforwardness."<ref>Khadduri (1984), p. 8</ref> In Islam, justice is not only a moral virtue but also an obligation to be fulfilled under all circumstances. The Quran at its two hundred places warns people against injustice, and at its one hundred places directs people to establishing justice.<ref name= Khadduri-10>Khadduri (1984), p. 10</ref> The Quran served for the early Muslims, as it serves for the present Muslims, as the primary source for the notion of justice. As his capacity as a prophet, the Quranic notion of justice was explained and translated into practice by Muhammad in dealing with various social issues, thus setting moral and legal examples and standards of justice in society and paving ways for the later Muslim theologians and scholars to "formulate theories of justice".<ref name= Khadduri-10/> The obligation to establish justice comes as a fundamental principle in the Quran, second in importance only to the [[Tawhid|oneness of God]].<ref name= Khadduri-10/> The Quranic injunction of fairness and fair dealing is equally applicable to all people, irrespective of caste, creed, and color.<ref name=Justice-1>[http://www.islamreligion.com/articles/376/justice-in-islam/ Justice in Islam.] 2006. ''IslamReligion.com'' Retrieved 19 Aug 2016.</ref> According to the scholars of the Quran, rendering justice to people is a trust from God entrusted on mankind, and this should be fulfilled with a sense of responsibility, not just as a formality.<ref name=Justice-1/>
===Fulfillment of promise=== In Islamic sharia, fulfilling a contract is regarded as compulsory,<ref>Maariful Quran. Chapter 17, verse 34.</ref> and is one of the three qualities necessary for becoming a true Muslim,<ref name=MQ-2-177>Maariful Quran. Chapter 2, verse 177.</ref> as the famous hadith says "Three are the signs of a hypocrite, even if he observed fast and prayed and asserted that he was a Muslim: when he spoke he told a lie, when he made promise he acted treacherously, and when he was trusted he betrayed" ({{Hadith-usc|usc=yes|muslim|1|113}}). Both the Quran and the hadith have attached importance to respect a contract once it has been made, and whether the other party is a Muslim or non-Muslim.<ref name=Ghazali-9>Al-Ghazali, chp. 9.</ref> Apart from the ordinary verbal promises, fulfillment of business contracts and repayment of loans come as a special instruction for the Muslims. Business contracts and words are not to be breached in pursuance of more profits. Similarly, admonition has been issued against the non-payment of loans as it is said to ruin the afterlife of a believer.<ref name=Ghazali-9/>
In Islamic tradition, fulfillment of promises has some other dimensions. Islamic belief holds that before creating humans in this world, God assembled their souls and asked them if He was not their Lord upon which they replied in the affirmative. Thus, accepting [[Allah]] as true God and following His commands in all sphere of life is regarded as the greatest fulfillment of that covenant.<ref>Maariful Quran. Chapter 7, verse 172.</ref> Again, in case of [[Marriage in Islam|Muslim marriage]], full payment of [[Mahr]] – the amount of money which a bridegroom needs to pay to the bride at the time of their marriage – has been emphasized. Non-payment, partial payment, or manipulation of mahr (jointure) is seen as the disruption of marriage contract.<ref name=Ghazali-9/> A hadith in Tibrani says "If a man has married a woman and in his heart he has the intention of not paying that mahr, then he has deceived her. If he dies and he has not paid her right, then on the [[Last Judgment|Day of Judgment]] he will be presented before Allah as a rapist. And a man who has borrowed money from another man while he did not have the intention of re-paying the debt, then he has deceived him, and consequently he defrauded him. If he dies in this condition, without paying back his debt, then he will meet Allah as a thief."
===Modesty and humility=== "Every religion has its characteristic, and the characteristic of Islam is modesty." This saying of Muhammad, collected in [[Muwatta Imam Malik|al-Muwatta]], shows the unique position [[modesty]] holds in Islam. Islam has strongly emphasized the concept of decency and modesty. Here, modesty is seen no less important in speech and behavior than in dressing. Again, modesty has a dual aspect in Islam: modesty is to be maintained in public which is generally related to people, as well as in private which is related to God.<ref name=modesty-1>Imam Kamil Mufti (2006). [http://www.islamreligion.com/articles/21/modesty-part-1/ Modesty: An Overview.] ''IslamReligion.com'' Retrieved 19 Aug 2016.</ref> Islam expects that a Muslim who believes in [[God in Islam|God]] will feel shy in front of God, and this shyness will prevent him from disobeying God, from committing any sinful or immodest act, whether in public or private, because he has awareness of God.<ref name=modesty-1/> Muhammad has said, "Modesty is part of faith" ({{Hadith-usc|bukhari|usc=yes|8|73|139}}). Thus Islam has linked modesty with faith. Islam also expects that a Muslim will be polite in his behavior with others. Display of anger, indecent behavior, or indecent exposure of body parts are highly discouraged. Modesty is seen as a human trait that distinguishes human beings from other animals.<ref name=modesty-1/><ref>Turner, Bryan S. (2008). ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=9gznc28-sg8C&pg=PA5 The Body and Society: Explorations in Social Theory.]'' p. 5. SAGE. {{ISBN|9781412929875}}</ref> Muhammad has been described as being more bashful than a maiden.<ref name=Shibli-2/>
Modesty in dressing has particularly been emphasized. According to [[Sharia|Islamic Law]], known as sharia, Muslims are required to cover their body parts with proper dressing.<ref name=Long-93>Long (2011), p.93</ref> Sharia has also laid down specific guidelines for men and women regarding their dressing. Covering everything from 'navel to knee' is mandatory for men.<ref name=Long-93/> In some Muslim societies, women wear the [[niqab]], a veil that covers the whole face except the eyes, or the full [[burqa]], a full-body covering garment that occasionally does cover the eyes. Following is the most frequently cited verse of the Quran regarding modesty: "Tell the believing men to lower their gaze and be modest. That is purer for them. God is Aware of what they do. And tell the believing women to lower their gaze and be modest, and to display of their adornment only that which is apparent, and to draw their veils over their chests, and not to reveal their adornment" ({{cite quran|24|30-1|s=ns|b=n}}).
[[Humility]] is defined as being modest and respectful. The prophetic narrations and Muhammad's own examples of simplicity and humbleness inspire the Muslims to practice humility in their life. According to tradition, Muhammad was rare to engage in argument with others. He was rare to laugh in a loud voice; rather, he preferred soft smiling.<ref name=Shibli-2/> During the conquest of Mecca, when Muhammad was entering into the city riding on a camel, his head lowered, in gratitude to God, to the extent that it almost touched the back of the camel.<ref name=Shibli-2/><ref>Khan (1980), p. 234</ref>
===Decent speech=== Islam has instructed its followers to maintain decency in speech, and misuse of tongue has been admonished. Excessive or absurd talking, or useless gossiping are generally discouraged.<ref name=Ghazali-11>Al-Ghazali, chp. 11.</ref> The person who talks too much is seen as having greater chances of making mistakes. Speech that hurts others' feelings or insults people are prohibited. Similarly, calling someone by any name that harms the honor of the person is prohibited. Decent and gentle speech has been encouraged as it is seen both as a virtue and as a means of cultivating goodness among people.<ref name=Ghazali-11/> Muhammad has preferred maintaining silence than engaging in meaningless talks. [[Polemic]]s in speech or heated arguments with ignorant people are disapproved of in Islam. In The Quran and the hadith, there are many instructions regarding the decent use of tongue. Some of them are:
* "The faith of a man cannot be straight unless his heart is straight, and his heart cannot be straight unless his tongue becomes straight." ([[Musnad Ahmad Ibn Hanbal|Musnad Ahmad]]) * "The faltering of the feet cause much less harm than the faltering of the tongue." (Baihaqui) * Muhammad once advised Abu Zar in this way: "Adopt silence. This is a way of causing Satan to run away, it is a support to you in the matter of your religion." ([[Musnad Ahmad Ibn Hanbal|Musnad Ahmad]]) * "Before Allah the most hated are the quarrelsome person" ({{Hadith-usc|bukhari|usc=yes|3|43|637}}). * “Successful indeed are the believers who are humble in their prayers, and who shun vain conversation, and who are active in deeds of charity." (Quran {{cite quran|23|1-4|s=ns|b=n}}) * "Say to my servants that they should say those things that are best. Verily, Satan sows discord among them. Verily, the Satan is for man an open enemy." (Quran {{cite quran|17|53|s=ns|b=n}}) * “A kind word with forgiveness is better than charity followed by injury. Allah is Free of All Wants and Most Forbearing." (Quran {{cite quran|2|263|s=ns|b=n}}) * "And argue not with the People of the Book unless it be in a better manner than that." (Quran {{cite quran|29|46|s=ns|b=n}})
===Trustworthiness=== [https://en.oxforddictionaries.com/definition/trustworthiness Trustworthiness], which is connected to fulfilling assigned responsibilities properly, has a wide field of application in Islam and conveys a wide range of meaning.<ref name=MQ-4-58>Maariful Quran. Chapter 4, verse 58.</ref> Islam has made every person responsible for returning the trust to their due recipients; and this command applies to both the common people and the ruling men.<ref name=MQ-4-58/> Misappropriation or breach of trust has been condemned severely. [[Anas ibn Malik]] narrates that there was hardly any occasion where Muhammad had delivered a speech but he had not said this "The person who lacks trustworthiness also lacks [[Iman (concept)|faith]]. And the person who does not keep promises has no religion."<ref name=MQ-4-58/> Muhammad has said, "Every one of you is a guardian and everyone will be asked about his subjects. Imam is a guardian. He will be asked about his subjects. A man is the guardian of the persons in his household. He is answerable about them. A woman is the guardian of her husband's house. She will be asked about her responsibility. The servant is the guardian of the articles of his master. He is answerable about this responsibility of his" ({{Hadith-usc|usc=yes|muslim|20|4496}}).
Performing one's duty sincerely and honestly is a trust. It means that a person will have the intention to properly carry out the duties entrusted to him, and will do it in the best possible manner without indulging in corruption.<ref name= Ghazali-8>Al-Ghazali, chp. 8.</ref> Receiving undue advantages from office is seen as corruption. The [[Head of state|rulers of the state]] or the [[Official|government officials]] who do not care for the [[Welfare state|welfare of their citizens]] and thus cause sufferings to them are seen as the worst deceiver and have been warned with the direst consequences in [[Akhirah|afterlife]].<ref name= Ghazali-8/> Adi bin Umaira narrates that he has heard the Prophet as saying: "Whomsoever we have given some post and he has concealed a needle or a thing smaller than that, then it will be a misappropriated thing with which he will have to appear on the Day of Judgment" ({{Hadith-usc|usc=yes|muslim|20|4514}}). Similarly, trust demands that posts be offered to able and deserving persons: persons who will be able to keep the [[Trust (emotion)|trust]] of organizations. To deny the public posts to those whose deserve them most, or to make appointments at public posts through [[nepotism]] is seen as misappropriation against God, His messenger, and the people. Those who make such unfair appointments have been warned that their prayers would not be accepted, and hell would be their destination.<ref name=MQ-4-58/><ref name= Ghazali-8/> Sahih Bukhari narrates that a man asked Muhammad when the Doomsday would occur. Muhammad replied "When deposits in trust would start being lost, then wait for the Doomsday." He was asked again, "What is the meaning of loss of trusts?" He replied: "When responsibilities are entrusted to unfit persons, then wait for the Doomsday" ({{Hadith-usc|bukhari|usc=yes|8|76|503}}).
According to Islamic theology, the wealth and abilities given to a man is a trust from God which means that they should be used in [[dīn|ways recommended by God]], and these should not be abused for illegal activities.<ref name= Ghazali-8/>
Protecting the confidential information of the meetings and the secret information of others is also a trust provided that these are not related to [[haram|illegal activities]].<ref name= Ghazali-8/> Disclosing family secrets, especially that of the [[wife]], is seen as the worst type of misappropriation. It is narrated in [[Sahih Muslim]] that "On the Day of Judgment before Allah, the greatest act of misappropriation will be that a man may love his wife and the wife may also be inclined towards her husband and then he may disclose his wife's secrets to others."
After Muhammad started his preaching in 610 CE, his relationship with his own tribesmen, [[Quraysh (tribe)|the Quraysh people]], deteriorated gradually.<ref name=EI-Muhammad/> Despite this, the Quraysh people of [[Mecca]] used to deposit their valuable things at Muhammad because of his honesty and trustworthiness.<ref name=Shibli-1>Shibli Nomani, vol 1</ref> When [[Hegira|Muhammad was compelled to leave Mecca]] because of Quraysh opposition, he directed his cousin [[Ali]] to return those deposits at their due recipients after his leave.<ref name=Shibli-1/>
===Patience=== {{See also|Sabr}} The issue of [[patience]] is of special interest in Islam. Islamic tradition holds that God has made this world a testing ground for mankind, especially for the believers, and that the sincerity and strength of their faith will be judged through various trials.<ref>Al-Ghazali, chp. 16.</ref> Patience is one of the moral qualities which Islamic sharia considers necessary for a Muslim in order to keep away from evildoings, and in a broader sense, to protect his [[Iman (concept)|faith]].<ref name=MQ-2-177/> This is because Islamic holy scriptures say that believers will be tested with various adversaries in their life, and only those who can prove their faith and can remain grateful to God despite those adversaries will earn His blessings.<ref>Maariful Quran. Chapter 2, verse 155.</ref><ref>Maariful Quran. Chapter 29, verse 2-3.</ref><ref name=Leaman-554>Leaman (2006), p. 554</ref> In Islamic theology, the solution to any crisis in a Muslim's life lies in two things: prayer and patience ([[Quran]] {{cite quran|2|153|s=ns|b=n}}), and Muslims have been asked to seek God's help through these two things.<ref name=Leaman-554/><ref>Maariful Quran. Chapter 2, verse 153.</ref>
===Truthfulness=== [[Honesty|Truthfulness]] has been much emphasized in Islam, not only as a virtue, but also as a [[Ahkam|religious obligation]]; and falsehood has been admonished severely. Islam demands that its followers lead their life on the basis of truthfulness and fair dealing. Falsehood and dishonesty must be avoided because they mark [[Fasiq|departure from religion]].<ref name=Ghazali-7>Al-Ghazali, chp. 7.</ref> Telling lie is one of the major sins in Islam.<ref>Imam Birgivi, p. 236</ref> Muhammad was asked whether a Muslim could be a coward. He answered: 'Yes.' He was asked whether a Muslim could be a miser. He answered: 'Yes.' He was again asked: 'Can a Muslim be a liar?' He replied: 'No.' Falsehood is seen as something which is against the general characteristics of human nature: it corrupts the [[Ruh|human soul]] and paves the way for many other evil activities.<ref name= Ghazali-7/> According to the Quran, truthfulness was a characteristic virtue of the [[prophets in Islam|prophets]] ([[Quran]] {{cite quran|12|46|s=ns|b=n}}; {{cite quran|19|41|s=ns|b=n}}; {{cite quran|19|54|s=ns|b=n}}; {{cite quran|19|56|s=ns|b=n}}; {{cite quran|5|75|s=ns|b=n}}).
Islam has some other considerations regarding truthfulness: * The virtue of truthfulness is to be maintained even in matters which are not serious in nature. Telling lies in jokes, or inventing false stories to amuse people are highly discouraged.<ref name= Ghazali-7/> * Telling lies to even children is prohibited. Prophetic tradition narrates that "Anybody who called a child saying that he would give him a certain thing, and did not give it, then it is a lie" (Ahmed). Children should be accustomed to truthfulness from their childhood so that they can grow up with this virtue.<ref name= Ghazali-7/> * Inventing falsehood and false story about God and His messengers, or inventing any [[bid'ah|false element in religion]] is seen as a grave sin.<ref name= Ghazali-7/><ref>Imam Birgivi, p. 238</ref> * Exaggeration in praising someone is prohibited. Exaggerated praising of any powerful of rich person in order to get illegal advantage falls into this category. Praise should be made to the extent a person knows about someone.<ref name= Ghazali-7/> [[Abu Hurairah]] narrates that "the Prophet has commanded us that we should throw dust in the face of those who indulge in exaggeration in their praises" ([[Sunan al-Tirmidhi|Tirmizi]]). * Giving false evidence against someone is seen as the worst type of falsehood, and is considered a major sin in Islam. A person is required to maintain truth in giving evidence even if that goes against their own interest.<ref name= Ghazali-7/> * Bringing [[False accusation|false charge]] of [[Zina|adultery]] against any woman is a punishable act in [[Sharia|Islamic law]] which orders to flog the accuser eighty lashes.<ref>Maariful Quran. Chapter 24, verse 4.</ref>
===Anger management=== [[Anger management]] comes as an important issue in Islamic tradition as anger is seen to destroy human [[conscience]] and to become the cause of many evil and violent activities.<ref name="Al-Ghazali, chp. 14"/> Anger is considered one of the characteristic features of pre-Islamic period – a period known as [[Jahiliyyah|age of ignorance]]. A hadith in [[Sunan al-Tirmidhi|Tirmizi]] says, "Adam's sons have been created of different types. … the best people among these are those who get angry late and immediately repent." In a famous hadith Narrated Abu Huraira, Muhammad said "The strong is not the one who overcomes the people by his strength, but the strong is the one who controls himself while in anger" ({{Hadith-usc|bukhari|usc=yes|8|73|135}}). Controlling anger is seen as a virtue and a sign of righteous person.<ref>Aisha Stacey (2012). [http://www.islamreligion.com/articles/5236/anger-management-in-islam-part-1/ Anger management in Islam: Controlling anger is a sign of righteousness.] ''IslamReligion.com'' Retrieved 19 Aug 2016.</ref> Muhammad is reported as suggesting several methods to assuage anger for a man when he gets angry: to sit down if he is standing, and/or to lie down if he is sitting; to perform [[Ablution in Islam|ablution]] (Islamic way of washing hands and face); to seek refuge from God against the influence of Satan.<ref>Aisha Stacey (2012). [http://www.islamreligion.com/articles/5240/anger-management-in-islam-part-2/ Anger management in Islam: Islam offers several methods to overcome anger and rage.] ''IslamReligion.com''</ref>
===Sincerity=== In Islam, [[sincerity]] of [[Niyyah|intention]] determines the significance of any act, that is to say, the value of any act depends on the motivation behind the act, not on the act itself.<ref name= Ghazali-10>Al-Ghazali, chp. 10.</ref> Good intention is said to earn reward and God’s pleasure while bad intention God's displeasure. In Islamic theology, this applies not only to general act but also to prayers and worshiping. Thus, any act of worshiping which is done to attain worldly fame, or any act of charity which is given to impress people, is considered invalid and is regarded as a sinful act by [[Sharia|Islamic jurisprudence]].<ref name= Ghazali-10/> Only those acts of prayer or charity which are done to seek God's pleasure or to benefit people are granted by God.<ref>Maariful Quran. Chapter 22, verse 37.</ref> In Islam, sincerity of intention has some other significances: a) if a person sincerely intends to do any good deed and then becomes unable to materialize it into action due to any reason, he is still said to get reward for it; b) an act of worshiping done to gain worldly fame and not to seek God's pleasure is regarded as lesser [[Shirk (Islam)|shirk]]; c) the reward for a righteous act increases from ten to thousand times depending on the sincerity of the doer's intention.<ref name= Ghazali-10/>
===Respecting the elders=== The family and the social tradition in Islamic world has long fostered the idea of respecting the elders of family and society.<ref>Rassool (2014), p. 64</ref><ref name=Haddad-94>Haddad, Yvonne Yazbeck. [https://books.google.com/books?id=Lv4RDAAAQBAJ&pg=PA94 Muslim Women in America: The Challenge of Islamic Identity Today]</ref> Elders are generally honored by the young members as part of both [[Islamic culture]] and religious duty. It is one of the important [[Adab (Islam)|Islamic good manners]] found in Islamic world. Examples of respecting elders include, among others, not walking ahead of the elders, allowing them to talk first in meetings, avoiding argument with them, and not raising voice before them.<ref name=Rasool-65>Rassool (2014), p. 65</ref> Prophetic tradition narrates that 'he who does not love the younger and does not respect the elders is not one of us'<ref name=Rasool-65/> ([[Sunan al-Tirmidhi]]). Anas inb Malik narrates that Muhammad said, 'If a young man honors an elderly on account of his age, Allah appoints someone to honor him in his old age'<ref name=Rasool-65/> ([[Sunan al-Tirmidhi]]).
Islamic traditions generally do not separate the older into [[Retirement home|old homes]], rather accommodate them into their own houses.<ref name=Haddad-94/> They are also respected as the guardian of the house. Among the elderly members of a family, the parents occupy a special position in case of receiving veneration by their children. With regard to the [[Islam_and_humanity#Rights_of_various_groups_in_Islam|rights of parents]], the Quranic injunction is to behave well with then, to take care of them especially in their old age, not to be rude to them, and to show highest respect to them.<ref>Maariful Quran. Chapter 17, verse 23-24.</ref><ref>Leaman (2006), p.489</ref>

''[https://books.google.com/books?id=zPXu561ZpvgC&pg=PT283 Islam For Dummies.]'' John Wiley & Sons. {{ISBN|978-1-118-05396-6}}. * Hashmi, Sohail H., ed. (2009). ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=5LmXFpnp_bMC&pg=PA68 Islamic Political Ethics: Civil Society, Pluralism, and Conflict]''. Princeton University Press. {{ISBN|9781400825370}}. * D'Silva, Joyce; Jacky Turner, ed. (2012). ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=2FzflX03FsMC&lpg=PA129 Animals, Ethics and Trade: The Challenge of Animal Sentience.]'' Routledge. {{ISBN|9781136571695}}. * Khadduri, Majid (1984). [https://books.google.com.in/books?id=td3XttHLGsEC&pg=PA6 The Islamic Conception of Justice]. The Johns Hopkins University Press. {{ISBN|9780801869747}} * Khan, Muhammad Zafrullah (1980). ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=baw9AAAAIAAJ&pg=40 Muhammad: Seal of the Prophets.]'' Routledge & Kegan Paul. {{ISBN|0-7100-0610-1}}. * Leaman, Oliver (2006). ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=isDgI0-0Ip4C&pg=PA252 The Qur'an: An Encyclopedia.]'' Taylor & Francis. {{ISBN|9780415326391}}. * Long, Matthew (2011). ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=H_m14NlQQMYC&pg=PA93 Islamic Beliefs, Practices, and Cultures.]'' Marshall Cavendish Corporation. {{ISBN|978-0-7614-7926-0}}. Retrieved 2 September 2014. * ''[[Maariful Quran]]'' (exegesis of the Quran) by [[Muhammad Shafi Usmani]]. [[Karachi]]. * Nigosian, S. A. (2004). ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=my7hnALd_NkC&pg=PA116 Islam: Its History, Teaching, and Practices.]'' [[Indiana]]: [[Indiana University Press]]. {{ISBN|0-253-21627-3}} * Rassool, G.Hussein, ed. (2014). [https://books.google.com/books?id=iUsdBQAAQBAJ&pg=PA64 Cultural Competence in Caring for Muslim Patients.] Palgrave Macmillan. {{ISBN|9781137358417}} * [[Shibli Nomani]]. ''[[Sirat-un-Nabi]]''. [[Lahore]]. * Stefon, Matt, ed. (2010). ''Islamic Beliefs and Practices.'' [[New York City|New York]]: [[Britannica Educational Publishing]]. {{ISBN|978-1-61530-060-0}}.

revision.text:
[[File:Wands09.jpg|thumb|right|150px|Nine of Wands from the [[Rider-Waite|Rider-Waite Tarot deck]]]] '''Nine of Wands''' is a [[Minor Arcana]] [[Tarot]] card.
==Divinatory purposes== This card depicts a figure, weary from battle yet prepared to fight on. Order, discipline an unassailable position. Any opposition will be defeated. Courage in the face of attack or adversity and a stability that cannot be removed. Good health.
'''Dignified or Reversed''' - Lack or inability to give and take. Projects pursued that are destined to fail because of their impractical nature. Delays and disarray. Card could indicate possible poor or ill health. A secure position that is no longer. Personality flaws may, in fact, be stepping-stones to the throne of harmony.
==Key Meanings== The key meanings of the Nine of Wands:<ref>Trusted Tarot (2010) [http://www.trustedtarot.com/cards/nine-of-wands/ Nine of Wands]</ref> *Afraid *Cautious *Defensive *Impermanent Security *Inner strength
==References== <!--<nowiki> See http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Footnotes for an explanation of how to generate footnotes using the <ref> and </ref> tags, and the template below. </nowiki>--> <references/>
{{Minor_Arcana}}
[[Category:Suit of Wands]]
{{tarot-stub}}

{{other uses|Panchjanya (newspaper)}}
{{unreferenced|date=February 2009}} [[Image:Vishnu.jpg|frame|right|Vishnu holding Panchajanya in his upper left hand]] '''Panchajanya''' ([[IAST]]: pāñcajanya) is the [[Shankha]] or [[conch]] of the [[Hinduism|Hindu]] god [[Vishnu]]. According to the [[Ramayana]], Purushottama (Vishnu) killed a [[Danava (Hinduism)|Danava]] (demon) named Panchajana on a mountain named Chakravan<ref>or "in another universe" ''When Lord Buddha achieved enlightenment, he saw millions and millions of “chakravan” or cosmoses, all repeatedly coming into existence, lasting for a while, and then disintegrating.'' {{Cite book|last=Thepyanmongkol |first=Phra |year=2007 |title=Sunday Dhamma Talks, volume 1 |location=[[Ratchaburi Province]], Thailand |publisher=Wat Luang Phor Sodh Buddhist Meditation Institute |page=[https://books.google.com/books?id=_SDwAQAAQBAJ&pg=PA29 29]}}</ref> constructed by [[Vishwakarma]] and took away the conch shell in which Panchajanya had lived. The conch was named after the Danava.
As per the [[Harivamsa]], Krishna, the avatar of Vishnu, is described as possessing a conch shell called Panchajanya, one of his four attributes together with the mace [[Kaumodaki]], the disc-like weapon [[Sudarshana Chakra]] and a [[Padma (attribute)|lotus flower]]. The conch was used during the [[Kurukshetra War]]. Panchajanya or Shankhasur was an evil sea demon who lived in a colossal conch shell in the deepest depths of the Prabhasa ocean or was a demon in the form of a conch shell. He kidnapped the son of Sandipani, the guru of Shri [[Krishna]], [[Balarama]], [[Sudama]],and Uddhava and imprisoned him in the conch shell. Upon completion of their studies, Krishna, Balarama, and Uddhava persuaded the teacher to ask for the preceptor’s dakshina (fees) of his liking. Sandipani asked for, as his dakshina, the restoration of his child. Krishna became enraged when he heard about the kidnap and plunged into the sea to rescue the son of Sandipani. Krishna successfully slew Shankhasur and took the conch shell for himself. He then went to his guru Sandipani who named that conch as Panchjanya .Whenever Krishna blows from the shell it foreshadows the death of his next opponent. The [[Kurukshetra War|great war]] of the ''Mahabharata'' began after blowing Panchjanya by Lord Krishna.
Vishnu is said to be quad-armed and he is depicted holding in one of his hands the panchajanya conch, which, like other shastras, has been transferred to lord Krishna on earth from the so-called heaven- Vaikuntha dhama. Lord Krishna found him in a deep sea. A demon used to sleep in this conch and thus was destined to be killed by holy god, at the time of receiving the conch.
==References== <references />
[[Category:Hindu mythology]]
{{Hindu-myth-stub}}

revision.comment: /* President of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints */
revision.text:
{{About|the position of President of the Church in the wider [[Latter Day Saint movement]]|information about this position specific to the LDS Church|President of the Church (LDS Church)}}
In the [[Latter Day Saint movement]], the '''President of the Church''' is generally considered to be the highest office of the church. It was the office held by [[Joseph Smith]], founder of the movement, and the office assumed by many of Smith's claimed successors, such as [[Brigham Young]], [[Joseph Smith III]], [[Sidney Rigdon]], and [[James Strang]]. Several other titles have been associated with this office, including '''First Elder''' of the church,<ref name = firstelder/> '''Presiding High Priest''',<ref name = PHP>{{lds|Doctrine and Covenents|dc|107|65-66}} (LDS Church edition).</ref> '''President of the High Priesthood''',<ref name = PHP/> '''Trustee-in-Trust''' for the church,<ref>''[[History of the Church (Joseph Smith)|History of the Church]]'' '''4''':517.</ref> '''Prophet''',<ref name = PSRT>{{lds|Doctrine and Covenents|dc|107|91-92}} (LDS Church edition).</ref> '''Seer''',<ref name = PSRT/> '''Revelator''',<ref name = PSRT/> and '''Translator'''.<ref name = PSRT/> Joseph Smith was known by all of these titles in his lifetime (although not necessarily with consistency).
[[Death of Joseph Smith, Jr.|Smith died]] in 1844 without having indisputably established who was to be his successor. Therefore, his death was followed by a [[succession crisis (Latter Day Saints)|succession crisis]] in which various groups followed leaders with succession claims. Years later, the office of President was reorganized in many of the resulting [[:Category:Latter Day Saint denominations|Latter Day Saint denominations]], the largest of which are [[The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints]] (LDS Church), the [[Community of Christ]] (formerly the Reorganized Church of Jesus Christ of Latter Day Saints), and [[The Church of Jesus Christ (Bickertonite)]]. Some smaller denominations, such as the [[Church of Christ (Temple Lot)]], reject the office as an unscriptural creation.<ref name = templelot>William A. Sheldon, [https://web.archive.org/web/20070423084901/http://www.churchofchrist-tl.org/latter.html "A Synopsis of Church of Christ Beliefs as compared to other Latter Day Saint churches"] (Church of Christ, n.d.).</ref>
==Joseph Smith: the first president== [[Image:Ovalportrait-josephsmith-Carter.jpg|thumb|right|[[Joseph Smith]], the founder of the [[Latter-day Saint movement]]]] The concept that the [[Church of Christ (Latter Day Saints)|Church of Christ]] would have a single presiding officer arose in late 1831. Initially, after the church's formation on April 6, 1830, Joseph Smith referred to himself as merely "an apostle of Jesus Christ, and elder of the church."<ref>''[http://josephsmithpapers.org/paperSummary/articles-and-covenants-circa-april-1830-dc-20?p=1 Articles and Covenants of the Church of Christ]'', June 9, 1830; see also: {{lds|Doctrine and Covenents|dc|20|2}} (LDS Church edition).</ref> However, there was one other [[Apostle (Latter Day Saints)|apostle]]—[[Oliver Cowdery]]—and several other [[Elder (Latter Day Saints)|elders]] of the church, making the formal hierarchy of the church unclear.
In September 1830, after [[Hiram Page]] claimed to have received [[Revelation (Latter Day Saints)|revelations]] for the church, a revelation to Smith stated that "no one shall be appointed to receive commandments and revelations in this church excepting my servant Joseph Smith, Jun., for he receiveth them even as Moses."<ref name=DC28:2,6-7>{{lds|Doctrine and Covenants|dc|28|2|,6-7|||x}} (LDS Church edition)</ref> This established Smith's exclusive right to lead the church.
In early June<ref>Different accounts of this meeting give the date as June 3, 4, or 6. [[Richard Bushman|Bushman]] considers June 3 to be the "best guess" for the date.</ref> 1831, Smith was ordained to the "high priesthood",<ref name="Minute Book 2, 3 June 1831"/><ref>Note that in the Minute Book 2 entry, Smith first ordains [[Lyman Wight]] and four other men "to the high priesthood", and Wight in turn ordains eighteen other men, including Smith, "to the high priesthood".</ref><ref>Compare this with the [[Priesthood (Latter Day Saints)#Restoration of the Aaronic Priesthood|Restoration of the Aaronic Priesthood]], where Smith first baptizes Oliver Cowdery, and is then in turn baptized by Cowdery.</ref> along with twenty-two other men, including prominent figures in the Latter Day Saint movement such as [[Hyrum Smith]], [[Parley P. Pratt]], and [[Martin Harris (Latter Day Saints)|Martin Harris]].<ref name="Minute Book 2, 3 June 1831">{{cite book |contribution-url= http://josephsmithpapers.org/paperSummary/minute-book-2?locale=eng&p=5 |contribution= 3 June 1831 |title= [http://josephsmithpapers.org/paperSummary/minute-book-2 Minute Book 2] |pages= 3–4}}</ref><ref name=Bushman>{{cite book |last= Bushman |first= Richard Lyman |authorlink= Richard Bushman |title= [[Joseph Smith: Rough Stone Rolling]] |publisher= Vintage Books |year= 2007 |location= New York |pages= 156–157, 202, and 595 |isbn= 978-1-4000-7753-3}}</ref> As "[[High Priest (Latter Day Saints)|high priests]]", these men were higher in the priesthood hierarchy than the [[Elder (Latter Day Saints)|elders]] of the church. However, it was still unclear whether Smith and Cowdery's calling as [[Apostle (Latter Day Saints)|apostles]] gave them superior authority than that of other high priests.
On November 11, 1831, a revelation to Smith stated that "it must needs be that one be appointed of the high priesthood to preside over the Priesthood and he shall be called President of the high priesthood of the Church ... and again the duty of the President of the high priesthood is to preside over the whole church."<ref>{{lds|Doctrine and Covenants|dc|107|64|-65,91-92|||x}} (LDS Church edition)</ref> Smith was ordained to this position and sustained by the church on January 25, 1832, at a conference in [[Amherst, Ohio|Amherst]], [[Ohio]].<ref name=Bushman/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.josephsmith.net/article/prophet-seer-and-revelator|title=Prophet Seer, and Revelator: Like Unto Moses|accessdate=2007-05-25|year=2007|work=Joseph Smith: Life of the Prophet|publisher=[[The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints]]}}</ref>
In 1835, the ''Articles and Covenants of the Church of Christ'' were revised,{{citation needed|date=March 2014}} changing the phrase "an ... elder of the church" to "the first elder of this Church."<ref name = firstelder>{{lds|Doctrine and Covenants|dc|20|2}} (LDS Church edition)</ref> Thus, subsequent to 1835, Smith was sometimes referred to as the ''First Elder'' of the church. The 1835 revision also added a verse referring to the office of "president of the high priesthood (or presiding elder)",<ref>{{lds|Doctrine and Covenants|dc|20|67}} (LDS Church edition)</ref> which had since been added to the church hierarchy.
==Removal== {{see also|Common_Council_of_the_Church#Trial_of_Joseph_Smith.2C_Jr.|l1=Common Council of the Church}} Though there has never been a popular movement in the church to have a president removed or punished, he could theoretically be removed from his position or otherwise disciplined by the [[Common Council of the Church]].<ref>{{lds|Doctrine and Covenants|dc|107|82|84}} (LDS Church edition)</ref> The only president of the church brought before the Common Council was [[Joseph Smith]], who was tried for charges made against him by [[Sylvester Smith (Latter Day Saints)|Sylvester Smith]] after the return of [[Zion's Camp]] in 1834.<ref>[[Joseph Fielding Smith]] (1953). ''Church History and Modern Revelation'' (Salt Lake City: Council of the Twelve Apostles) '''2''':21.</ref> The Council determined that Joseph Smith had "acted in every respect in an honorable and proper manner with all monies and properties entrusted to his charge."<ref>''[[History of the Church (Joseph Smith)|History of the Church]]'' '''2''':143.</ref>
==President of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints== [[File:Russell_M._Nelson.png|right|thumb|[[Russell M. Nelson]], President of [[The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints]]|150px]] {{main|President of the Church (LDS Church)}} {{see also|List of presidents of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints}} The President of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints is the church's leader and the head of the [[First Presidency (LDS Church)|First Presidency]], the church's highest governing body. [[Latter-day Saint]]s consider the president of the church to be a ''[[prophet, seer, and revelator]]'', and refer to him as ''the Prophet'', a title originally given to [[Joseph Smith]]. When the name of the president is used by adherents, it is usually prefaced by the title [[President (LDS Church honorific)|"President"]]. Latter-day Saints consider the president of the church to be God's spokesman to the entire world and the highest [[Priesthood (LDS Church)|priesthood]] authority on earth, with the exclusive right to receive revelations from God on behalf of the entire church or the entire world. The President of the Church serves as the head of the [[Council on the Disposition of the Tithes]] and the head of the [[Council of the Church]]. The President of the Church also serves as the [[ex officio]] chairman of the [[Church Educational System|Church Boards of Trustees/Education]].
==Prophet-Presidents of the Community of Christ == {{see also|List of Prophet-Presidents of the Community of Christ}} In the [[Community of Christ]], formerly the Reorganized Church of Jesus Christ of Latter Day Saints (RLDS), the president of the church's formal title is the ''Prophet-President''.{{citation needed|date=March 2014}} The Prophet-President is the highest [[priesthood (Latter Day Saints)|priesthood]] leader of the church. The position is composed of several roles: (1) ''President of the Church'', (2) ''President of the High Priesthood'' and (3) ''[[Prophet, Seer, and Revelator]]'' to the church.
As ''President of the Church'', the Prophet-President is the church's chief executive and is the leader of the [[First Presidency (Community of Christ)|First Presidency]], the church's chief executive council. As ''President of the High Priesthood'', the Prophet-President is the church's leading priesthood official. (Since the initiation of the ordination of women in 1985, it is now possible for this position to be filled by a woman, though all Prophet-Presidents to date have been men.) As ''[[Prophet, Seer, and Revelator]]'', the Prophet-President is the Community of Christ's spiritual leader and can present revelations to the church to be added to the [[Doctrine and Covenants]]—an open canon of scripture, which stands with the [[Bible]] and the [[Book of Mormon]] as sacred text. In the church, only the Prophet-President is considered to be a prophet, seer, and revelator, and so far, each person to hold this position has presented additional revelations or spiritual writings to the church, which have been added to the Doctrine and Covenants.
===Succession to the Presidency=== Generally, the Prophet-President will name or ordain a successor prior to his death or retirement. The office was traditionally referred to as President of the High Priesthood. Prior to 1995, these successors had been chosen consistent with [[Lineal Succession (Latter Day Saints)|lineal succession]], even though it was not a church rule. Accordingly, the first six Prophet-Presidents following movement founder [[Joseph Smith]] were his direct descendants.
In 1995, [[Wallace B. Smith]] broke with the precedent of lineal succession by naming [[W. Grant McMurray]] as his successor. In November 2004, McMurray resigned from the office of Prophet-President without naming a successor, citing medical and personal issues. The First Presidency, composed of McMurray's two counselors, continued to function as the church's chief executive council. A [[Joint Council (Community of Christ)|Joint Council]] of church leaders led by the [[Council of Twelve Apostles (Community of Christ)|Council of Twelve Apostles]] announced in March 2005 that [[Stephen M. Veazey]] would be Prophet-President designate. Veazey had been serving as [[President of the Quorum of the Twelve|president of the Council of Twelve]]. Delegates elected to a special [[World Conference (Community of Christ)|World Conference]] of the church approved Veazey and he was ordained as the Prophet–President on June 3, 2005.
==Remnant Church of Jesus Christ of Latter Day Saints== The [[Remnant Church of Jesus Christ of Latter Day Saints]] continues to believe in the lineal succession through the [[inheritance|Jewish Laws of Inheritance]]. As such, the president of the Remnant Church, [[Frederick Niels Larsen]], is a direct descendant (maternal 2nd great-grandson) of Joseph Smith, Jr.
==President of The Church of Jesus Christ (Bickertonite)== [[File:Paul Palmieri.jpeg|thumb|right|[[Paul Palmieri (The Church of Jesus Christ)|Paul Palmieri]], President of [[The Church of Jesus Christ (Bickertonite)]]]] {{see also|List of presidents of The Church of Jesus Christ (Bickertonite)}} Similar to other denominations in the [[Latter Day Saint movement]], in [[The Church of Jesus Christ (Bickertonite)]], the ''President of the General Church'' is also a member of the [[Quorum of Twelve Apostles (Bickertonite)|Quorum of Twelve Apostles]].
==President of the Church of Jesus Christ (Cutlerite)== The tiny [[Church of Jesus Christ (Cutlerite)]], headquartered in [[Independence, Missouri]], has a First Presidency with a President and two Counselors. Succession generally goes to the First Counselor at the time of the previous President's death or resignation (no Cutlerite president has ever resigned), subject to approval of the church membership.
==President of the Fundamentalist Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints== In the earliest years of its existence, the [[Mormon fundamentalism|Mormon fundamentalist]] [[Short Creek Community]] regarded [[The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints]] (LDS Church) as "the only true and living church," viewing itself merely as a "body of Priesthood" set apart to perpetuate [[plural marriage]] and other "crowning ordinances" of the Gospel, such as the [[United Order]]. Hence, they tended to express a degree of admiration for contemporary LDS Church Presidents, while simultaneously insisting that they had compromised on serious matters and did not truly hold the "keys of the Presidency of the Church," which had allegedly been returned to the spirit world at the death of [[Joseph F. Smith]] in 1918. Thus, they generally valued Church direction less than direct pronouncements from their own [[Council of Friends (Woolley)|Priesthood Council]]. This "Council of Friends" consisted of seven "[[Apostle (Latter Day Saints)|High Priest Apostles]]" or "Presiding High Priests," the seniormost of whom was considered "President of the Priesthood" or Prophet.
Following LDS Church President [[Spencer W. Kimball]]'s [[1978 Revelation on Priesthood]], extending the right of ordination to black African males in perceived contradiction to the teachings of [[Brigham Young]] and other early LDS leaders, the fundamentalists in [[Colorado City, Arizona]], and [[Hildale, Utah]], began to regard their parent organization as a "complete Gentile sectarian church." In 1991, [[Rulon Jeffs]], by that time sole surviving member of the Priesthood Council and thus Prophet of the group, incorporated his followers into "the Corporation of the President of the [[Fundamentalist Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints]]" or FLDS Church, with himself as President. Upon his death in 2002, Jeffs was succeeded by his First Counselor and son, [[Warren Jeffs]]. Despite the younger Jeffs' resignation from the Presidency in 2011 following his imprisonment for child sexual assault, and a brief tenure by [[Wendell Loy Nielsen]] as President of the Church's corporate assets, most FLDS members continue to regard Jeffs as a prophet.
==Latter Day Saint sects without a President of the Church== Some sects in the Latter Day Saint movement do not accept the office of President of the Church as a valid office in the priesthood; these groups often maintain that because Jesus' original church was led by twelve apostles, not by a president or a three-man presidency, the latter-day church should be similarly organized.<ref name = templelot/> For instance, the [[Church of Christ (Temple Lot)]] is governed by a [[Quorum of the Twelve]]; the members of the quorum are generally regarded as co-equal holders of the highest office in the church.
==See also== {{Portal|History of the Latter Day Saint movement|LDS Church}} *[[Assistant President of the Church]] *[[We Thank Thee, O God, for a Prophet]]
==References== {{reflist|2}} {{-}} {{Latter Day Saint movement}}
